title: Ryan Zimmerman, Max Scherzer lead Nationals to win against Dodgers, forcing Game 5
text:
USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — Because he’s been here since the beginning, they call him The Franchise.

So it was fitting that Ryan Zimmerman’s three-run blast in the fifth inning put Game 4 of the NLDS out of reach and propelled the Washington Nationals to a 6-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers, providing the Nationals another opportunity to capture their first postseason series victory since the franchise moved back to the nation’s capital in 2005, the year Zimmerman debuted for the Nats.

Four games into a rematch of the 2016 NLDS that also went the limit, the two teams have split the two contests at both Dodger Stadium and Nationals Park. They’ll now play a decisive Game 5 back in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

Zimmerman’s clutch homer paved the way for Washington starter Max Scherzer, who overcame a shaky start and threw up zeros the rest of the way. At one point, he retired 12 of 13 batters and finished with seven strikeouts in seven innings.

Game Ball

The moment may have belonged to Zimmerman, but Scherzer did exactly what the Nationals needed him to do – supply length and throw effectively enough to make sure an all-hands-on-deck situation from the bullpen could wait another day.

It was clear the three-time Cy Young Award winner didn’t have his best stuff in the early going, with two of the first five Dodgers hitting extra-base hits, but that quickly changed. He tamed the formidable Dodgers lineup through the middle innings and allowed four hits and three walks total. Scherzer punctuated his outing by escaping a bases-loaded, one-out jam in the seventh to keep the Nationals up by five.

Turning point

With the game tied 1-1, Turner led off the fifth with a single and Adam Eaton moved him to second on a sac bunt. Anthony Rendon, who'd driven in the first Nationals run with a sacrifice fly in the third, blooped one into left field for the Nationals’ first lead of the game. Howie Kendrick lined a knock into left-center to set up first and third, which brought Zimmerman to the dish.

Baez tried to challenge him upstairs with an 0-1 fastball. Zimmerman wasn’t caught by surprise, and he sent the ball 414 feet to dead center.

Seeing things out

The Nationals tacked on another run in the sixth when Turner led off with a double and Rendon plated him with a sacrifice fly to center that sent Bellinger crashing into the wall.

The bottom of Los Angeles' order loaded the bases against Scherzer with one out in the seventh. He fanned pinch-hitter Chris Taylor and when Joc Pederson pounded his 109th pitch of the night into the ground toward second base for the third out, the 35-year-old was visibly pumped while strolling off the mound.

There were no bullpen theatrics from the Nationals in this one. Sean Doolittle retired all four hitters he faced and Daniel Hudson shut the door with the final two outs in the ninth.

State of the series

All that's at stake in Game 5 is a berth to the NLCS. For the Dodgers, it'd mark the fourth consecutive season they advance to that round. The Nationals franchise (even as the Expos) has never won a playoff series.

The pitching matchup features right-hander Walker Buehler for the Dodgers and Stephen Strasburg for the Nationals. Buehler was lights out in the opening contest of the series, throwing six one-hit frames with eight strikeouts. Strasburg was almost as good the next night (one run allowed) and fanned 10 over six innings in a Game 2 win.
description: The Washington Nationals even the series with the Dodgers after a gutsy performance from Max Scherzer in Game 4.
